category.text: $course$/Experiencing MIS, 9e (Kroenke)/001 Chapter 1 The Importance of MIS

name.text: q001 The number of transistors per square inch on an integrated chip doubles eve

questiontext.text: The number of transistors per square inch on an integrated chip doubles every 18 months. This observation is known as ________ Law.

name.text: q002 Which of the following statements is TRUE of Moore's Law?

questiontext.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE of Moore's Law?

answer.text: It is based on the technological advancements in weapon manufacturing.
It made the cost of data processing, communications, and storage essentially zero.
It states that the total number of transistors produced in the world doubles every 18 months.
It has made the use of transistors obsolete.

name.text: q003 Which of the following is a result of Moore's law?

questiontext.text: Which of the following is a result of Moore's law?

answer.text: The risk of technology becoming obsolete has decreased.
The price to performance ratio of computers has fallen dramatically.
The outsourcing of nonroutine skills has increased drastically.
The cost of data processing has increased considerably.

name.text: q004 Which of the following best describes why Introduction to MIS is the most i

questiontext.text: Which of the following best describes why Introduction to MIS is the most important course in the business school today?

answer.text: Business students need to be able to assess, evaluate, and apply emerging information technology to business.
Business students have to concentrate more on developing routine skills than nonroutine skills.
Business students need to be able to develop better communication and information technologies.
Business students no longer need to focus on skills such as abstract reasoning and collaboration.

name.text: q005 ________ states that the value of a network is equal to the square of the n

questiontext.text: ________ states that the value of a network is equal to the square of the number of users connected to it.

questiontext.text: Which of the following laws speaks about the storage density on magnetic disks?

name.text: q007 Moore's Law states that the speed of a computer doubles every 18 months.

questiontext.text: Moore's Law states that the speed of a computer doubles every 18 months.

name.text: q008 Future business professionals need to be able to apply information technolo

questiontext.text: Future business professionals need to be able to apply information technology to business.

name.text: q009 The number of businesses adopting new technologies has seen a downfall over

questiontext.text: The number of businesses adopting new technologies has seen a downfall over the years.

name.text: q010 Define Moore's Law and explain how the phenomenon described by it affects b

questiontext.text: Define Moore's Law and explain how the phenomenon described by it affects business.

graderinfo.text: Moore's Law states that the number of transistors per square inch on an integrated chip doubles every 18 months. The more common version of this is expressed as, "The speed of a computer chip doubles every 18 months," which is incorrect. Due to the impact of Moore's Law, the price to performance ratio of computers has fallen dramatically. Moore's Law is the principal reason why data storage and data transmission are essentially free today. Major businesses including YouTube and Facebook have taken advantage of the opportunities offered by this development.

name.text: q011 As the cost of data processing, storage, and communications is essentially

questiontext.text: As the cost of data processing, storage, and communications is essentially zero, any routine skill can and will be ________.

name.text: q012 Which of the following is an impact of rapid technological change on job se

questiontext.text: Which of the following is an impact of rapid technological change on job security?

answer.text: Nonroutine cognitive skills have gained more market value.
Nonroutine jobs are outsourced, thus reducing the need of an in-house workforce.
Routine skills are no longer required to complete a task.

name.text: q013 Which of the following statements is TRUE of nonroutine cognitive skills?

questiontext.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE of nonroutine cognitive skills?

answer.text: They increase an individual's job security.
They do not experience the impact of technological changes.
They are usually outsourced by organizations to the lowest bidder.

name.text: q014 ________ is the ability to make and manipulate models.

questiontext.text: ________ is the ability to make and manipulate models.

name.text: q015 ________ is the ability to model the components of a unit to connect the in

questiontext.text: ________ is the ability to model the components of a unit to connect the inputs and outputs among those components into a sensible whole that reflects the structure and dynamics of the phenomenon observed.

name.text: q016 Which of the following best describes collaboration?

questiontext.text: Which of the following best describes collaboration?

answer.text: It is the ability of an individual to model the components of the system, to connect the inputs and outputs among those components into a sensible whole that reflects the structure and dynamics of the phenomenon observed.
It is the ability to assess, evaluate, and apply emerging information technology to business.
It is the activity of two or more people working together to achieve a common goal, result, or work product.
It is the activity of constructing or modifying models with the help of one's nonroutine cognitive skills.

name.text: q017 In a job interview, Lillian is asked to be part of a three-member group and

answer.text: modeling the components of a system

questiontext.text: The knowledge of managing information systems can lead to greater job security.

name.text: q024 A marketable skill has no impact on job security.

questiontext.text: A marketable skill has no impact on job security.

name.text: q025 Strong nonroutine cognitive skills are more in demand than routine skills.

questiontext.text: Strong nonroutine cognitive skills are more in demand than routine skills.

name.text: q026 Abstract reasoning is one of the components of strong nonroutine cognitive

questiontext.text: Abstract reasoning is one of the components of strong nonroutine cognitive skills.

name.text: q027 Critical feedback undermines collaboration.

questiontext.text: Critical feedback undermines collaboration.

name.text: q028 The fear that paralyzes good people and good ideas is called fear of failur

questiontext.text: The fear that paralyzes good people and good ideas is called fear of failure.

name.text: q029 Professionals in the 21st century need to be able to experiment in order to

questiontext.text: Professionals in the 21st century need to be able to experiment in order to have greater job security.

name.text: q030 Successful experimentation is characterized by the investment of huge sums

questiontext.text: Successful experimentation is characterized by the investment of huge sums of money at every idea that enters one's head.

name.text: q031 When a user is provided with an unfamiliar program and asked to use it, he

questiontext.text: When a user is provided with an unfamiliar program and asked to use it, he or she is being tested on their ability to collaborate effectively.

name.text: q032 What is a marketable skill?

questiontext.text: What is a marketable skill?

graderinfo.text: A marketable skill used to be that one could name particular skills, such as computer programming, tax accounting, or marketing, as examples of marketable skills. But today, because of Moore's Law, because the cost of data processing, storage, and communications is essentially zero, any routine skill can and will be outsourced to the lowest bidder. One has to develop strong nonroutine cognitive skills to be more successful and such skills are called marketable skills. Abstract reasoning, systems thinking, collaboration, and the ability to experiment are also classified as marketable skills.

name.text: q033 What is abstract reasoning?

questiontext.text: What is abstract reasoning?

graderinfo.text: Abstract reasoning is the ability to make and manipulate models. Constructing a model from the five components of an information system is an example of abstract reasoning.

name.text: q034 What is systems thinking?

questiontext.text: What is systems thinking?

graderinfo.text: Systems thinking is the ability to model the components of a system, to connect the inputs and outputs among those components into a sensible whole that reflects the structure and dynamics of the phenomenon observed. It shows how components' inputs and outputs relate to one another.

name.text: q035 What is collaboration? How can one ensure effective collaboration?

questiontext.text: What is collaboration? How can one ensure effective collaboration?

graderinfo.text: Collaboration is the activity of two or more people working together to achieve a common goal, result, or work product. It means to develop ideas and plans with others in a team and to provide and receive critical feedback. Effective collaboration is not about being nice. Surveys indicate the single most important skill for effective collaboration is to give and receive critical feedback.

name.text: q036 What is experimentation? Explain its importance.

questiontext.text: What is experimentation? Explain its importance.

graderinfo.text: Experimentation is making a reasoned analysis of an opportunity, envisioning potential solutions, evaluating those possibilities, and developing the most promising ones, consistent with the resources one has. Fear of failure paralyzes many good people and many good ideas. This can be overcome by having the ability to experiment.

name.text: q037 The mismatch between the high level of tech skills demanded by employers an

questiontext.text: The mismatch between the high level of tech skills demanded by employers and the low level of tech skills held by employees is known as ________.

name.text: q038 According to Accenture, CEOs plan to use less artificial intelligence (AI)

questiontext.text: According to Accenture, CEOs plan to use less artificial intelligence (AI) for automation.

name.text: q039 ________ refers to the products, methods, inventions, and standards that ar

questiontext.text: ________ refers to the products, methods, inventions, and standards that are used to produce information.

name.text: q040 Which of the following statements is TRUE about information systems?

questiontext.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE about information systems?

answer.text: They can be bought off the shelf.
They are a group of components that produce information.
They drive the development of information technology.
They are not susceptible to the changing needs of the market.

answer.text: An employee must be a programmer to manage information systems.

questiontext.text: Why is it important for business professionals to take an active role in developing and managing information systems?

answer.text: They know how to create a database and configure computers.
They are the people who know how to build networks.
They know whether a system meets their needs and requirements.
They are the lone users of information systems.

questiontext.text: Which of the following is a critical responsibility of business professionals in using information systems?

answer.text: protecting the security of a system and its data
reprogramming a system to meet changing needs
creating and modifying a system's databases

name.text: q049 Information systems and information technology are not the same.

questiontext.text: Information systems and information technology are not the same.

name.text: q050 Information systems can be bought, whereas information technology cannot be

questiontext.text: Information systems can be bought, whereas information technology cannot be bought.

name.text: q051 An information system is a group of components that interact to produce inf

questiontext.text: An information system is a group of components that interact to produce information.

name.text: q052 The methods used to start a program and save a file are referred to as proc

questiontext.text: The methods used to start a program and save a file are referred to as procedures.

name.text: q053 Building information systems requires many different skills besides those o

questiontext.text: Building information systems requires many different skills besides those of programmers.

name.text: q054 The use of information systems is restricted to the field of business.

questiontext.text: The use of information systems is restricted to the field of business.

name.text: q055 Information systems should be created by a business only if they help achie

questiontext.text: Information systems should be created by a business only if they help achieve the strategies of that business.

name.text: q056 Explain the difference and the relationship between information technology

questiontext.text: Explain the difference and the relationship between information technology (IT) and information systems (IS).

graderinfo.text:
Information technology and information systems are two closely related terms, but they are different. Information technology (IT) refers to the products, methods, inventions, and standards that are used for the purpose of producing information. IT pertains to the hardware, software, and data components. An information system (IS) is an assembly of hardware, software, data, procedures, and people that produces information. Information technology drives the development of new information systems.
Users can buy IT; they can buy or lease hardware, they can license programs and databases, and they can even obtain predesigned procedures. Ultimately, however, it is the people who execute those procedures to employ the new IT.
For any new system, users will always have training tasks (and costs), they will always have the need to overcome employees' resistance to change, and they will always need to manage the employees as they use the new system. Hence, one can buy IT, but not IS.

name.text: q057 Describe an information system.

questiontext.text: Describe an information system.

graderinfo.text: A system is a group of components that interact to achieve some purpose. An information system (IS) is a group of components that interact to produce information. An IS is based on the five-component framework of computer hardware, software, data, procedures, and people. These five components are present in every information system–regardless of task complexity.

name.text: q058 Describe the five components of an information system using an example.

questiontext.text: Describe the five components of an information system using an example.

graderinfo.text: The five components of an information system are computer hardware, software, data, procedures, and people. For example, when one uses a computer to write a class report, he or she is using hardware (the computer, storage disk, keyboard, and monitor), software (Word, WordPerfect, or some other word-processing program), data (the words, sentences, and paragraphs in his or her report), procedures (the methods he or she uses to start the program, enter his or her report, print it, and save and back up his or her file), and people (an individual).

name.text: q059 Define management information system. What are the key elements of its defi

questiontext.text: Define management information system. What are the key elements of its definition?

graderinfo.text: A management information system is the management and use of information systems that help businesses achieve their strategies. This definition has three key elements: management and use, information systems, and strategies.

name.text: q060 Explain the management and use of information systems.

questiontext.text: Explain the management and use of information systems.

graderinfo.text: Information systems must be developed, maintained and, because business is dynamic, they must be adapted to new requirements. To create an information system that meets specific needs, one will have to take an active role in that system's development. In addition to management tasks, he or she will also have important roles to play in the use of information systems. For example, when using an information system, there will be responsibilities for protecting the security of the system and its data. One may also have tasks for backing up data.

name.text: q061 What are the points that one should keep in mind when deciding to implement

questiontext.text: What are the points that one should keep in mind when deciding to implement a management information system (MIS)?

graderinfo.text: When deciding to implement an MIS, one needs to keep in mind that information systems are not created for exploring technology. They are not created so that the company can be "modern" or so that the company can show it has a social networking presence on the Web. They are not created because the information systems (IS) department thinks they need to be created or because the company is "falling behind the technology curve." Information systems exist to help people who work in a business to achieve the strategies of that business.

name.text: q062 Which choice is not considered a definition of "information"?

questiontext.text: Which choice is not considered a definition of "information"?

answer.text: Information is recorded facts or figures.
Information is data presented in a meaningful context.
Information is a difference that makes a difference.

questiontext.text: ________ is defined as recorded facts or figures.

answer.text: If it depicts numbers, the printed graph it is information.

answer.text: Because the data might be outdated.
Because information is not always accurate.
Because the other person may be color blind and can not view the colors in the document.
Because people perceive different information from the same data.

questiontext.text: The definition for information is easy to define.

name.text: q067 Everyone views data as the same and will make the same conclusions.

questiontext.text: Everyone views data as the same and will make the same conclusions.

name.text: q068 Why are humans the most important part of any information system you use wh

questiontext.text: Why are humans the most important part of any information system you use when it comes to information?

graderinfo.text: The quality of your thinking, of your ability to conceive information from data, is determined by your cognitive skills. The data is just the data; the information you conceive from it is the value you add to the information system.

questiontext.text: List the characteristics of good data.

graderinfo.text: The characteristics of good data are accurate, timely, relevant (to context and to subject), just barely sufficient, and worth its costs.

name.text: q084 What is the Information Age?

questiontext.text: What is the Information Age?

graderinfo.text: We are now living in the Information Age. This is a period in history where the production, distribution, and control of information are the primary drivers of the economy. The Information Age started in the 1970s with the Digital Revolution.

name.text: q090 Describe what causes many good people with good ideas to not try their idea

questiontext.text: Describe what causes many good people with good ideas to not try their idea.

graderinfo.text: Fear of failure: the fear that paralyzes so many good people and so many ideas. Some people are afraid to experiment with their ideas. Successful experimentation is not throwing buckets of money at every idea. Experimentation is making a reasoned analysis of an opportunity, envisioning potential solutions, evaluating those possibilities, and developing the most promising ones.

name.text: q099 Why is Metcalfe's Law a fundamental force changing digital devices?

questiontext.text: Why is Metcalfe's Law a fundamental force changing digital devices?

graderinfo.text:
Another fundamental force that is changing digital devices is Metcalfe's Law, named after Robert Metcalfe, the inventor of Ethernet. Metcalfe's Law states that the value of a network is equal to the square of the number of users connected to it. In other words, as more digital devices are connected together; the value of that network will increase. Metcalfe's Law can be clearly seen in the dramatic rise of the Internet in the 1990s. As more users gained access to the Internet, it became more valuable. The dot-com boom ushered in tech giants like Google, Amazon, and eBay. None of these companies would have existed without large numbers of users connected to the Internet.
Metcalfe's Law isn't lost on tech companies, either.

name.text: q100 All of the following are true of experimentation EXCEPT ________.

questiontext.text: All of the following are true of experimentation EXCEPT ________.

answer.text: whenever an idea pops in your head throw lots of money at it to see if it works

name.text: q101 List the reasons why this MIS course is the most important in the business

questiontext.text: List the reasons why this MIS course is the most important in the business school.

graderinfo.text:
1. It will give you the background you need to assess, evaluate, and apply emerging information systems technology to business.
2. It can give you the ultimate in job security–marketable skills–by helping you learn abstraction, systems thinking, collaboration, and experimentation.
3. Many well-paid MIS-related jobs are in high demand.

name.text: q004 Briefly describe how organizational strategy determines the functions of in

questiontext.text: Briefly describe how organizational strategy determines the functions of information systems.

graderinfo.text: Organizations examine the structure of their industry and determine a competitive strategy. This strategy determines value chains, which, in turn, determine business processes. The structure of business processes determines the design of supporting information systems.

name.text: q028 Describe Porter's five forces model.

questiontext.text: Describe Porter's five forces model.

graderinfo.text: Organizational strategy begins with an assessment of the fundamental characteristics and structure of an industry. One model used to assess an industry structure is Porter's five forces model. Porter developed the five forces model to help organizations determine the potential profitability of an industry. Over the years, this model has also been applied to understand organizations' competitive environments. Porter's five competitive forces can be grouped into two types: forces related to competition and forces related to supply chain bargaining power. The competitive forces include competition from vendors of substitutes, competition from new competitors, and competition from existing rivals. The bargaining power forces include the bargaining power of suppliers and the bargaining power of customers. The intensity of each of the five forces determines the characteristics of the industry, how profitable it is, and how sustainable that profitability will be. Organizations examine these five forces and determine how they intend to respond to them. This examination leads to development of competitive strategies.

name.text: q029 An organization responds to the structure of its industry by choosing a ___

questiontext.text: An organization responds to the structure of its industry by choosing a ________ strategy.

name.text: q030 Which of the following competitive strategies does a company follow if it p

questiontext.text: Which of the following competitive strategies does a company follow if it produces a uniquely formulated anti-aging face cream targeted at women above the age of forty?

answer.text: providing the lowest cost across the industry
providing a better product across the industry
focusing on lowering the cost within an industry-segment
focusing on product differentiation within an industry-segment

name.text: q031 A firm introduces a new range of laptops that concentrate on delivering goo

answer.text: increasing the price of its product when raw material prices increase

advertising its products nationwide like its competitor organizations
launching a unique product targeted at a section of consumers

name.text: q033 According to Porter, to be effective, an organization's goals, objectives,

questiontext.text: According to Porter, to be effective, an organization's goals, objectives, culture, and activities must be consistent with the organization's ________.

name.text: q034 An organization can choose to either minimize cost or maximize differentiat

questiontext.text: An organization can choose to either minimize cost or maximize differentiation to gain a competitive advantage.

name.text: q035 Focused differentiation is a strategy in which a product is unique and is u

questiontext.text: Focused differentiation is a strategy in which a product is unique and is used by a wide range of consumers.

name.text: q036 According to Porter, all information systems in the organization must facil

questiontext.text: According to Porter, all information systems in the organization must facilitate the organization's competitive strategy to be effective.

name.text: q037 What are the four competitive strategies based on Porter's five forces mode

questiontext.text: What are the four competitive strategies based on Porter's five forces model?

graderinfo.text: An organization responds to the structure of its industry by choosing a competitive strategy. Porter defined four fundamental competitive strategies. According to Porter, a firm can engage in one of these four fundamental competitive strategies. An organization can focus on being the cost leader, or it can focus on differentiating its products from those of the competition. Further, an organization can employ the cost or differentiation strategy across an industry, or it can focus its strategy on a particular industry segment. In order to be effective, the organization's goals, objectives, culture, and activities must be consistent with the organization's strategy.

name.text: q038 Porter defined ________ as the amount of money that a customer is willing t

questiontext.text: Porter defined ________ as the amount of money that a customer is willing to pay for a resource, product, or service.

It consists of only primary activities.
It is specific to manufacturing industries.
It nullifies the importance of support activities.

questiontext.text: Value chain analysis has a direct application to manufacturing businesses.

name.text: q070 How does competitive strategy determine value chain structure?

questiontext.text: How does competitive strategy determine value chain structure?

graderinfo.text: Porter defined value as the amount of money that a customer is willing to pay for a resource, product, or service. A value chain is a network of value-creating activities. Organizations analyze the structure of their industry and formulate a competitive strategy using that analysis. They then need to organize and structure the organization to implement that strategy. If, for example, the competitive strategy is to be a cost leader, then business activities need to be developed to provide essential functions at the lowest possible cost. A business that selects a differentiation strategy would not necessarily structure itself around least-cost activities. Instead, such a business might choose to develop more costly systems, but it would do so only if those systems provided benefits that outweighed their risks.

name.text: q071 Distinguish between a primary and a support activity in the value chain.

questiontext.text: Distinguish between a primary and a support activity in the value chain.

graderinfo.text: Primary activities are business functions that relate directly to the production of an organization's products or services. Primary activities include inbound logistics, operations, customer service, and sales and marketing. These activities add value to a product. Support activities are business functions that assist and facilitate the primary activities. Supporting functions add value to a product indirectly. They also have costs and contribute to a margin. It is difficult to calculate their margins because the specific value added is difficult to measure.

name.text: q072 Differentiate between value and margin.

questiontext.text: Differentiate between value and margin.

graderinfo.text: Porter defined value as the amount of money that a customer is willing to pay for a resource, product, or service. The difference between the value that an activity generates and the cost of the activity is called the margin. A business with a differentiation strategy will add cost to an activity only as long as the activity has a positive margin.

name.text: q073 Describe the primary activities in a value chain using an example.

questiontext.text: Describe the primary activities in a value chain using an example.

graderinfo.text:
In a bicycle manufacturing unit, the primary activities of a value chain are followed. The manufacturer acquires raw materials using the inbound logistics activity. This activity concerns the receiving and handling of raw materials and other inputs. The accumulation of those materials adds value in the sense that even a pile of unassembled parts is worth something to some customer. A collection of the parts needed to build a bicycle is worth more than an empty space on a shelf. The value is not only the parts themselves but also the time required to contact vendors for those parts, to maintain business relationships with those vendors, to order the parts, to receive the shipment, and so forth.
In the operations activity, the bicycle maker transforms raw materials into a finished bicycle, a process that adds more value. Next, the company uses the outbound logistics activity to deliver the finished bicycle to a customer. Of course, there is no customer to send the bicycle to without the marketing and sales value activity. Finally, the service activity provides customer support to the bicycle users.

name.text: q074 What is a value chain? List the primary activities in a value chain.

questiontext.text: What is a value chain? List the primary activities in a value chain.

graderinfo.text:
A value chain is a network of value-creating activities. The generic value chain developed by Porter consists of five primary activities and four support activities. Primary activities are business functions that relate directly to the production of the organization's products or services. The primary activities are:
a. Inbound logistics–deals with receiving, storing, and disseminating inputs to the product.
b. Operations–involves transforming inputs into the final product.
c. Outbound logistics–deals with collecting, storing, and physically distributing the product to buyers.
d. Marketing and sales–involves inducing buyers to purchase the product and providing a means for them to do so.
e. Customer service–involves assisting customer's use of the product and thus maintaining and enhancing the product's value.

name.text: q075 Explain value chain linkages.

questiontext.text: Explain value chain linkages.

graderinfo.text: Porter's model of business activities includes linkages, which are interactions across value activities. For example, manufacturing systems use linkages to reduce inventory costs. Such a system uses sales forecasts to plan production; it uses the production plan to determine raw material needs and then uses the material needs to schedule purchases. The end result is just-in-time inventory, which reduces inventory sizes and costs. Value chain analysis has a direct application to manufacturing businesses and also exists in service-oriented companies.

name.text: q076 How did Porter define technology, human resources, and firm infrastructure?

questiontext.text: How did Porter define technology, human resources, and firm infrastructure?

graderinfo.text: Porter defined technology broadly. It includes research and development, but it also includes other activities within the firm for developing new techniques, methods, and procedures. Human resources include recruiting, compensation, evaluation, and training of full-time and part-time employees. Firm infrastructure includes general management, finance, accounting, legal, and government affairs.

name.text: q077 Describe the support activities in a value chain.

questiontext.text: Describe the support activities in a value chain.

graderinfo.text: Support activities are business functions that assist and facilitate the primary activities. The support activities in the generic value chain facilitate the primary activities and contribute only indirectly to the production, sale, and service of the product. They include procurement, which consists of the processes of finding vendors, setting up contractual arrangements, and negotiating prices. Porter defined technology broadly. It not only includes research and development, but it also includes other activities within the firm for developing new techniques, methods, and procedures. Human resources includes recruiting, compensation, evaluation, and training of full-time and part-time employees. Firm infrastructure includes general management, finance, accounting, legal, and government affairs. Supporting functions add value, albeit indirectly, and they also have costs.

name.text: q078 According to Porter, the processes and systems in an organization pursuing

questiontext.text: According to Porter, the processes and systems in an organization pursuing differentiation strategy must ________ to avoid negative margins.

answer.text: create sufficient value to cover their costs
provide products at lowest costs to customers

name.text: q079 Which of the following statements is TRUE of business processes?

questiontext.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE of business processes?

answer.text: If a value chain's margin is negative, the value should be decreased.
Value chain activities differ based on the business processes being used.
If a value chain's margin is negative, the costs of the value chain should be increased.
The processes implementing a value chain must create sufficient value to cover their costs.

name.text: q080 Business processes implement value chains or portions of value chains.

questiontext.text: Business processes implement value chains or portions of value chains.

name.text: q081 Each value chain is supported by one or more business processes.

questiontext.text: Each value chain is supported by one or more business processes.

name.text: q082 Value chain activities are not dependent on the competitive strategies used

questiontext.text: Value chain activities are not dependent on the competitive strategies used by organizations.

name.text: q083 Two companies with the same value chain activities will have the same busin

questiontext.text: Two companies with the same value chain activities will have the same business processes.

name.text: q084 If a value chain's margin is negative, the company must reduce the cost of

questiontext.text: If a value chain's margin is negative, the company must reduce the cost of the value chain.

name.text: q085 What is the criterion on which business processes should run?

questiontext.text: What is the criterion on which business processes should run?

graderinfo.text: According to Porter, whether business processes are low-cost or high-service, these processes and systems used must create sufficient value that they will more than cover their costs. If not, the margin of those systems will be negative. If a value chain's margin is negative, the company must make some change. Either the value must be increased, or the costs of the value chain need to be reduced.

name.text: q088 Which of the following is a process implementation principle of competitive

name.text: q090 Jupiter Shop is an online store. Customers have to create an online account

questiontext.text: Jupiter Shop is an online store. Customers have to create an online account to purchase products. The purchased products are delivered free of cost. The address of delivery is stored, so that customers can choose the same address for future purchases. Jupiter Shop features seasonal discounts and exchange offers. It also accumulates redeemable points for regular shoppers. Which of the following statements describes the use of information systems (IS) by Jupiter Shop to lock in customers?

name.text: q091 An information system can be part of a product, but it cannot provide suppo

questiontext.text: An information system can be part of a product, but it cannot provide support for a product or service.

name.text: q092 Raising barriers to market entry is a product implementation principle.

questiontext.text: Raising barriers to market entry is a product implementation principle.

name.text: q093 Establishing alliances with other organizations promotes product awareness.

questiontext.text: Establishing alliances with other organizations promotes product awareness.

name.text: q094 Enhancing existing products and services is a competitive advantage created

questiontext.text: Enhancing existing products and services is a competitive advantage created by the implementation of business processes.

name.text: q095 How can one develop competitive strategies using products? How can informat

questiontext.text: How can one develop competitive strategies using products? How can information systems help in the process?

graderinfo.text:
Some competitive techniques are created through products and services, while some are created through the development of business processes. There are three principles that concern products and services. Organizations gain a competitive advantage by creating new products or services, by enhancing existing products or services, and by differentiating their products and services from those of their competitors.
An information system can be part of a product or it can provide support for a product or service.

name.text: q096 Describe some competitive advantage strategies that are based on business p

questiontext.text: Describe some competitive advantage strategies that are based on business processes.

graderinfo.text:
Some of the competitive strategies that are based on business processes include:
1. Locking in customers–organizations can lock in customers by making it difficult or expensive for customers to switch to another product. This strategy is also called establishing high switching costs.
2. Locking in suppliers–organizations can lock in suppliers by making it difficult to switch to another organization, or, stated positively, by making it easy to connect to and work with the organization.
3. Creating entry barriers–competitive advantage can be gained by creating entry barriers that make it difficult and expensive for new competition to enter the market.
4. Establishing alliances–another means to gain competitive advantage is to establish alliances with other organizations. Such alliances establish standards, promote product awareness and needs, develop market size, reduce purchasing costs, and provide other benefits.
5. Reducing costs–organizations can gain competitive advantage by creating better business processes at reduced costs. Such reductions enable the organization to reduce prices and/or increase profitability.

name.text: q097 Ultimately, competitive strategy determines the structure, features, and fu

questiontext.text: Ultimately, competitive strategy determines the structure, features, and functions of every information system.
